reporting-org.narrative: FONDS VOOR ONTWIKKELINGSSAMENWERKING - SOCIALISTISCHE SOLIDARITEIT VZW

title.narrative: PROG 2017-2021_Outcome_Organizations of people in precarious living conditions have contributed to the improvement and the enforcement of labour rights and the right to social protection, including the right to health, with attention to the interests of both men and women.

description.narrative: The programme in Zimbabwe focusses on ILO pillars 2 and 3 of decent work, i.e. on improving labour rights and the access thereto, and the right to social protection and health for the beneficiaries and members of our partners’ organisations. The beneficiaries are men and women in precarious living and working conditions, mainly farm workers and members of rural communities, who try to organize themselves to change their circumstances and to demand their rights, with a specific focus on women and youth. Our partners provide education and information on rights, on organizing and on the socio-economic, political and environmental context; they build the confidence and empower their members/beneficiaries, specifically women, and stimulate them to unite in order to demand their rights. In addition to mobilizing communities and workers, our Zimbabwean partners will try to have an impact on decision making processes and the drafting, amending and enforcing of new and existing laws. They will do so through participating in social dialogue and collective bargaining platforms. They will support active community participation and awareness and they will try to make voices of precarious workers and communities heard in society.

title.narrative: Organizations of people in precarious living conditions have contributed to the improvement and the enforcement of labour rights and the right to social protection, including the right to health, with attention for the interests of both men and women.
Level of improvement in access to the right to social protection, including the right to health, as experienced and indicated by the target groups of the partners.

comment.narrative: Representatives of our partners’ target groups identify the following problems related to access to social protection and health: Vulnerable rural communities: - understaffed and under-resourced public health care system; long distances to health care providers, long waiting times - lack of representation of community members in HCC’s; farm dwellers excluded from participation in HCC; lack of legal foundation for HCC - lack of knowledge in communities about health rights and lack of confidence and of equal access to state institutions to demand those rights - lack of understanding of the importance of social determinants of health, including gender and environmental issues - lack of unity and solidarity and of organizing around health rights in vulnerable communities; lack of community participation and mobilization around health - lack of government support to community participation; no prioritization of equitable, fair and quality public primary health care by government Specific for women: - lack of maternity care and (expectant) mother and baby accommodation in healthcare facilities; - lack of child care for working mothers - lack of participation of women in health care dialogue structures - low health literacy In relation to the social determinants of health: - high impact of climate change and contamination; poor housing conditions; lack of access to water and electricity; food insecurity; gender based violence; teenage pregnancies; violence; high prevalence of HIV/aids and other communicable diseases; low self-esteem and confidence.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 2 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health.

The actions of partners contributed to improvements related to three problems concerning the access to the right to social protection, including the right to health: • lack of knowledge in communities about health rights and lack of confidence and of equal access to state institutions to demand those rights: CWGH’s health literacy programme strengthens the capacity of farm worker communities to take part in local primacy health care policy processes. They now have increased capacity to report violations of the right to health, amongst others. Furthermore, sensitisation programmes and capacity building programmes strengthened farm worker capacity to take part in their own health governance, both inside and outside of the workplace. • lack of participation of women in health care dialogue structures: Women’s forums are particularly critical for the programming on social protection; they are a platform for women to dialogue on health and gender issues that affect them, as well as bringing women’s concerns into national and regional policy dialogue. • lack of representation of community members in HCC’s; farm dwellers excluded from participation in HCC; lack of legal foundation for HCC: CWGH’s training and support to GAPWUZ’s shop stewards and community monitors, strengthens the link between occupational safety and health and community health as a whole, resulting in increased farm worker participation in HCC's. Communities are mobilised through GAPWUZ’s union structures in farming communities.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 3 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health.

The actions of partners contributed to improvements related to three problems concerning the access to the right to social protection, including the right to health: • Health Centre Committees (HCC) engaged in pro poor advocacy and lobbying: HCCs successfully lobbied local authorities for the re-opening of health centres closed during the land reform programme. Nine health centres have been reopened. Further, in the period under review, a health service corner was upgraded to a fully-fledged clinic, improving health literacy and health uptake. The strengthened lobby and advocacy capacity of HCCs may be attributed to the CWGH’s of HCCs in health governance. • Equal participation of men and women at HCC: CWGH reports an equal participation in HCC between men and women. Women’s participation in policy processes that affect them, including health governance is critical for the programming on social dialogue, including stimulating debate on women’s relational position to social determinants of health, access to health as well as social protection. There are also consorted efforts at working with NSSA on pensions, medical aid and maternity benefits as well as extending social protection to the informal economy. • lobby towards extending social protection to the informal economy LEDRIZ are leveraging on the Covid-19 induced increase in spaces for stakeholder dialogue to strengthen lobby and advocacy for the extension of social protection to the informal economy. The Covid-19 pandemic has exposed the extent of lack of decent work and how it disproportionately affects the poor, including the majority being workers in the informal economy, women, people living with disabilities and youth. Despite this, they still do not have access to protection/ social safety nets and a living wage.

title.narrative: Level of improvement in access to labour rights and reduction in labour market flexibility and informalisation as experienced and indicated by the target groups of the partners.

comment.narrative: Representatives of our partners’ target groups identify the following problems related to labour rights and labour conditions: General for all precarious workers: - very low wages and no adequate access to labour rights and social protection (paid maternity leave, sickness or invalidity benefits, pension, funeral cover) - late or non-payment of wages - decrease of permanent employment, high job insecurity and large scale use of new forms of flexible labour (e.g. seasonal labour, labour broker work, work without a formal contract) - lack of enforcement of labour laws; lack of inspections; lack of protection by the government; lack of alignment between the Constitution and the labour laws - employers do not respect agreed collective agreements or labour laws; government does not gazette CBA’s - lack of awareness of the general public on the issues of precarious workers - historically skewed and exploitative power relations; discrimination, sexism and harassment from managers, supervisors and employers, especially toward women - no freedom of association Specific for Agricultural Workers: - non-respect of minimum wages through quota - foreign (Chinese) company owners and individual farmers not complying with labour laws and social dialogue - poor working conditions in terms of health and safety - no home/land of their own

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 2 problems concerning access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation.

The actions of partners contributed to improvements related to four problems concerning access to labour rights: • very low wages and no adequate access to labour rights: GAPWUZ scored major victories at National Employment Council (NEC) level, successfully negotiating a review from annual wage negotiations to quarterly negotiations to factor in inflation. Furthermore, the union successfully bargained for a review wages and agreed on new wages of between 33. 99% to 68% across its seven sectors. Although the wages are still low and fall short in meeting the needs of workers they have mitigated the levels of poverty among working class communities. • late or non-payment of wages: GAPWUZ won two cases of back payment involving more than 200 workers. The workers have since been paid their salaries in full. • occupational safety and health for agricultural workers: GAPWUZ successfully pushed for the finalisation of the Agriculture Occupational Health and Safety Regulation at National Employment council, becoming the countries very first. • lack of awareness of the general public on the issues of precarious workers: Gender is mainstreamed across all of ZCTU’s collective bargaining processes ensuring that issues specific to women are carried through in all levels of the workplace and beyond. The commercial sector successfully bargained for the inclusion of sanitary ware in their sector bargaining. Through its programme on sexual harassment and combating patriarchy at the workplace, ZCTU recorded an increase the reporting of sexual harassment / violence in the workplace.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 4 problems concerning access to labour rights and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation.

The actions of partners contributed to improvements related to four problems concerning access to labour rights: • very low wages and no adequate access to labour rights: GAPWUZ scored major victories at National Employment Council (NEC) level, successfully negotiating a review from annual wage negotiations to quarterly negotiations to factor in inflation. Furthermore, the union successfully bargained for a review wage and agreed on new wages of between 33. 99% to 68% across its seven sectors. Although the wages are still low and fall short in meeting the needs of workers, they have mitigated the levels of poverty amongst working class communities. • occupational safety and health for agricultural workers: GAPWUZ successfully pushed for the finalisation of the Agriculture Occupational Health and Safety Regulation at National Employment council, becoming the countries very first. • lack of awareness of the public on the issues of precarious workers: Gender is mainstreamed across all ZCTU’s collective bargaining processes, ensuring that issues specific to women are carried through in all levels of the workplace and beyond. The commercial sector successfully bargained for the inclusion of sanitary products in their sector bargaining. Through its programme on sexual harassment and combating patriarchy at the workplace, ZCTU recorded an increase the reporting of sexual harassment / violence in the workplace. •Labour amendments Further to achievements realised in year three ; GAPWUZ successfully pushed for amendments to the principal regulation in agriculture Statutory Instrument (SI) 116 of 2014. The Instrument regulates conditions of service and the code conduct for the agriculture sector. The review of the instrument aligned it with the Labour Act. Among the new provisions are limitations to hours of work in line with the Labour Act. This saw a reduction of working hours from ten hours to eight hours for vulnerable workers such as security guards, herdsmen, boilermen, watchmen, fire tower attendants and pump attendants.
